@tqchen callback function, do you mean add_lower_pass in lower? 
```
cfg = BuildConfig.current
    add_lower_pass = cfg.add_lower_pass if cfg.add_lower_pass else []
    lower_phase0 = [x[1] for x in add_lower_pass if x[0] == 0]
    lower_phase1 = [x[1] for x in add_lower_pass if x[0] == 1]
    lower_phase2 = [x[1] for x in add_lower_pass if x[0] == 2]
    lower_phase3 = [x[1] for x in add_lower_pass if x[0] > 2]
```
But what I want is like this, dumping ir for **each pass**, is there a better way to do this in tvm?
```
+def static_vars(**kwargs):
+    def decorate(func):
+        for k in kwargs:
+            setattr(func, k, kwargs[k])
+        return func
+    return decorate
+
+@static_vars(num = 0)
+def save_ir(_str, stmt):
+    save_ir.num += 1
+    name = str(save_ir.num)+ "_"+_str + ".ir"
+    with open(name, 'w') as f:
+         print >> f, stmt

 def lower(sch,
           args,
@@ -209,19 +222,27 @@ def lower(sch,
     # Phase 0
     bounds = schedule.InferBound(sch)
     stmt = schedule.ScheduleOps(sch, bounds)
+    save_ir("ScheduleOps" , stmt)
     stmt = ir_pass.InjectPrefetch(stmt)
+    save_ir("InjectPrefetch" , stmt)
```

add your printer as a  callback function for add_lower_pass that runs the print and return the identical stmt, this will print out the result under certain phase.

If you want more in-depth hacking, hack up a lower function that does so is easier than simply add an official option to do so.
related issues https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/issues/230  https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/issues/206
@Laurawly might some tips, as this question is asked a few times, maybe it makes sense to have a master reference issue where we accumulate tips, without doing this repeatively

The way i'm thinking is add save_ir in convert_to_tvm_func or cfun, check if this is a pass call, add a save_ir for them, would this work for my case?

Maybe the best way is just add dump function in each pass in c++, and control them via a dump flag.
Please note that you do not have to do it, use cross compile mode instead. Build tvm on your desktop and set target compilation to be arch64
Adding such feature create additional lines without creating additional benefit, as you can already do so for debug purpose by just modifying the python script
see http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/deployment/cross_compilation_and_rpc.html#sphx-glr-tutorials-deployment-cross-compilation-and-rpc-py

to make use of ```add_lower_pass```, do 

```python
def print_ir(stmt):
     print logic here
     return stmt

# the following code insert a print pass at stage 0
with tvm.build_config(add_lower_pass=[(0, print_ir)]):
    tvm.lower(...)
```

IR dumping is useful, we prefer to do it in a composable way. So instead of have a bulk API that have a dump option, just use callback function or simply modify the lower script to insert the inspection we need at right place

Ok. So, after building the tvm runtime on my device I need to build tvm on my host right? According to this section: http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/cross_compilation_and_rpc.html#set-up-rpc-server-on-device 

Do I need to cross compile tvm on host or just native compile as mentioned here: http://nnvm.tvmlang.org/how_to/install.html ?
IRDeepCompare is a better choice than string comparison. Thanks!

Next step: Remove dependency on glfw and glad. I will focus on Ubuntu, since it should be the tricky one. Windows and Mac should have official APIs to create OpenGL contexts.

I will see what Ubuntu Desktop has by default and only depend on that.
On Ubuntu Server, OpenGL might not exist by default (because it doesn't have GUI). If that's the case I will see what minimum packages are needed to have OpenGL, and only depend on them.

Use `wgl*` functions you can create a context on Windows.

On Linux, if MESA is installed, OpenGL soft-rendering should be available as well as accelerated graphics, if there is a GPU. Compute Shader should be supported as it's a part of the OpenGL 4.3 spec.

FYI, without GLFW it will be your responsibility to query if a GL function is available. Using GL_ABR_compute_shader, the minimum GL version requirement should be (Core) 4.3. On initialization, GLFW stores function pointers to GL APIs so that the query results can be reused.

One of the the main goal here is to use WebGL, this means

- so the standard version should be less than OpenGL2.
- we cannot use compute shader

Please try to emscripten the GL runtime to see if we can successfully build it
You can just natively build tvm on your host

I see. But it would be nice if we can utilize the functionalities provided by OpenGL of higher versions - Compute Shader. We have Compute Shader support in OpenGL (Core) 4.3 and in OpenGL ES 3.1 but not yet in WebGL. In the current latest commit, you can see there is a [dummy vertex shader](https://github.com/phisiart/tvm/blob/e58817058fa1cac783556e8befd31be872851964/src/runtime/opengl/opengl_device_api.cc#L318-L325) that doesn't need to but has to be executed.

Or a strategy can be devised so that both shaders can do some work.
For most other devices, opencl is also available, which is more desirable than OpenGL itself

I understand you are suggesting to implement a stand-alone constant folder for CanonicalSimplify? 
- If yes, can't we somehow reuse HalideIR's simplifier? 
--  If yes, do you have a suggestion? I'm not sure what the best way is to do this.
--  If no, why?
- If no, can you elaborate?

After some experiments, I found that the following is the minimum requirements for `find_package(OpenGL REQUIRED)` in cmake to succeed.

Dockerfile:
```
FROM ubuntu

RUN apt-get update --fix-missing

RUN apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends \
  make cmake g++ libgl1-mesa-dev
```

CMake is looking for `libGL.so`, and on Ubuntu there are 3 packages that provide this (see [here](https://packages.ubuntu.com/search?suite=precise&arch=amd64&mode=filename&searchon=contents&keywords=libGL.so)):

- mesa: This is what comes by default when you install Ubuntu desktop;
- nvidia: The NVIDIA driver;
- fglrx: The AMD driver.

Therefore, we should depend on `libgl1-mesa-dev`.

Okay, I just tested and found out that on a fresh installation of Ubuntu Desktop you also need the package `libgl1-mesa-dev`, for `find_package(OpenGL REQUIRED)` in cmake to succeed (because Ubuntu doesn't come with the 'dev' version of the package).

TVM fails to detect the dependence here. You can explicitly add it when creating schedule
```python
s = tvm.create_schedule([ref.op, masked_data.op])
```

so far tvm does not yet optimizes for int8 which TensorRT is optimized for. But there are some on going effort on this, so answer is TensorRT is faster currently and we are keep improving TVM to cover optimizations used in TensorRT for all platforms

The general guideline when we designed CanonicalSimplify, is that it should be evolved to be self-sufficient for simplifying index expressions. So while it is possible to mix HalideIR's simplifier with this, we should patch it to have the same ability when it is easy to do so.  HalideIR's simplifier is complementary and can be used to simplify some more complicated expression including computation.

Eventually, we want to rethink the integer analysis here and build a unified simplifier that contains both symbolic integer and set analysis.

It is possible to also directly reuse HalideIR's simplifier. Note that so far Reduce is only used in very restricted case, as reduce is always the last expression of body. So we can simply have a function that strips reduce and use simplifier in the body
cc @derisavi-huawei @merrymercy let me know if it makes sense to you and see if any of you are interested in this
thanks for your answer

I totally understand the need for a unified simplifier you're talking about. I can see that no matter how much we incrementally improve the current simplifier(s), there will still be fundamental limitations. However, implementing the unified simplifier needs a fairly significant time investment. So my attempts now are to solve short-term problems and get a few more things to work.
Following your last paragraph, I'm working on some changes so that we can call HalideIR's simplifier on "TVM expressions" basically by passing through any non-HalideIR ops and simplifying the rest using HalideIR's simplifer. Hopefully, this approach makes it future-proof as we may add non-HalideIR ops other than reduce in the future. I'll try to finish it asap and send it for your comments.

Is this about an alternative way for TVM to generate IR for `reduce_axis`(so that it eventually leads to more efficient code on a particular hardware), or is it about what kind of patterns (init/update vs compute/update) tensorize can match, or both, or something else? In terms of interest, it's not something that will be on our radar in the next month or so. If we grow an interest in it, I'll definitely let you know.

I think it is a bug. if you put `ref` in the body of tvm.sum,  tvm can detect the dependency. But it fails when `ref` is in the condition.

It is related to https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/512 on comment in terms of the alternative way of generating reduction, and is useful when init intrinsic is not available due too limitation of hardware

- https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/pass/lower_intrin.cc#L36 which will redirect to LLVM's FMA 
- Even without doing so, LLVM will automatically generate FMA via pattern matching so we do not have to do it in TVM
seems to be a bug that should be fixed

can you please elaborate? for example a simple code snippet on what you want before and after transformation will put discussion into context

Sure,

suppose I have the following loop nest for convolution
-- before transformation
```
for(n)
    for(ff)  -- filter loop blocked by Vector Length(VLEN)
        for(h)
             for(w)
                 for f
                  output[n][ff][h][w][f] = 0
                   for(c)  -- reduction loop
                       for(r)  -- reduction
                            for(s)  --reduction
                                  for(f)  --  blocked filter loop
                                         output[n][ff][h][w][f] +=   input[n][c][h+r][w+s]*weight[ff][c][r][s][f]                                      
```

-- I call vectorize(f)

can I get something like:
--after transformation
```
for(n)
    for(ff)  -- filter loop blocked by Vector Length(VLEN)
        for(h)
             for(w)
                 for f
                  output[n][ff][h][w][f] = 0
                   for(c)  -- reduction loop
                       for(r)  -- reduction
                            for(s)  --reduction
                                 //for(f) -- loop vectorized
                                      **FMA(output,  broadcast(input), weight)//broadcast input to vector length**  
                                         //output[n][ff][h][w][f] +=   input[n][c][h+r][w+s]*weight[ff][c][r][s][f]                                      

```

Emscripten is compiling LLVM intermediate to JavaScript. It should require no linking to native libraries. Maybe we can just `extern "C"`-declare those APIs we need, so that the feature can be implemented with no dependency added.

See [this](https://www.khronos.org/registry/OpenGL/api/GLES2/gl2.h) for GLES2 APIs.

@PENGUINLIONG I think we want to support both running natively and in the browser.

A funny thing is that emscripten has direct support for glfw. If we remove the dependency on glfw then we would be calling native glx functions. I'm not sure whether emscripten has good support for those. I will look into it and report my findings.

@phisiart It seems Emscripten simply map the calls. See [this](https://github.com/kripken/emscripten/blob/master/src/library_gl.js). Then it's possible that we simply declare them and they will work.

However, it seems not possible we can create context without dependencies.
Yes, you should be able to use vectorize for this purpose.

Thanks for the clarification. When I print  using get_source I see 
llvm.fmuladd.v16f32 instructions. However when I save to assembly format, it is not getting lowered to fma. Instead it is getting lowered to a multiply followed by an add.
Looks like llvm is determining that the cost of an fma is more than the combined cost of a multiply and an add or is not detecting the presence of FMA instructions
Probably using the cross compile mechanism specifying the llvm target with the fma  flag would sort out this problem. I'll keep you updated.
Yes, this worked, adding the appropriate target fixed the problem, able to see fma instructions

@tqchen , I have a solution in my local now, as we discussed, firstly set the reset part as "None" in intrinsic definition, then transform the update part in tensorize.cc. I will send to u for review after some tests.

This is mainly due to a naming issue, as ib.for_range if we do not pass in name by default, will simply assign the same string name (which is i) to both i and j.

This is not a bug, since the code generation do not rely on name for uniqueness. But i agree this can be improved, possibly by introducing a auto naming mechanism in ir_builder, by maintaining a stack like structure.

Contribution is welcomed.

was mainly due to this is GPU schedule, we need either bind R to gpu threads or compute R inline. otherwise it will generate cpu code that access R and causes segfault

the option for the llvm is consistent with ```llc```.  Unfortunately there is not yet a command line way to set the unroller option in llvm optimization. The relevant code are in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/codegen/llvm/codegen_llvm.cc#L201

Test passed. Ready to merge.

For matrix multiplication C = A (1, 1024) x B (1000, 1024):
- llvm naive schedule for float dense is 1043us tested on Intel® Core™ i5-6600K CPU (single thread)
- binary dense is 16us (single thread)
-------------------------------------------------

For matrix multiplication C = A (1024, 1024) x B (1024, 1024):
- 1 thread binary dense: 46.1 ms
- 2 thread binary dense: 8.7 ms
- 4 thread binary dense: 4.6 ms

As we have noticed, the performance gain from 1 thread (46.1ms) to 2 thread (8.7ms) is too large and seems unreasonable.

When I remove ``s[C].parallel(s[C].op.axis[0])`` from the schedule, the result is 16.8 ms for single thread, much better than 46.1 ms.
